												Milestone set out to succeed playstation 2's Tourist Trophy as the modern motorcycle racing simulator. It however falls very short of that goal. Graphics are last generation quality that somehow taxes modern video cards. The only positive things I could say about the game is it's selection of bikes and gear. But it falls short from there. It feels very shallow and geared towards the casual gamer/racing fan. Short-comings in on track riding is what ruins the game the most. It is the same arcade style simulation (an oxymoron) engine as the previous MotoGP games. Trailbraking deep is ridiculous and offers no feedback when the front wheel is at it's limit. The reactions of the bike to too much throttle is the same for every bike. Turning into the first corner is always the same even if the race just started and the front tire is still "cold". Then there are the small missing details. No clutch lever use even on the older bikes. The throttle hand works but the brake lever is never used, never mind the rear brake pedal on the right foot. There are ZERO braking markers for non-track circuits. Only occasionally is there a reference point like a tree or a fence, but the rider is left with nothing to judge the approach most of the time.Then there's the ridiculously aggressive AI that has no qualms of ramming passed you because somehow collisions only penalize one bike. The AI will insist on it's line even if you're in front of it and worst of all will not brake if you plan on braking earlier than it. The AI is also on a very suboptimal line The set up of the game progression is obviously an afterthought to Milestone as there is NO QUALIFYING SESSION. YOU ARE ALWAYS 8TH. Leaving you with having to deal with the 7 AI-controlled bikes that will slow you down. Then there's the classification of the bikes into races. Some are beyond lazy such as grouping the MT07 with Ducati Monsters and Triumph Street triples because they are all below 700cc. WHAT?! That's a very ignorant way to classify a class race. The MT07 MAY have a corner speed advantage, but that advantage is completely blown away on circuits with straights. Why even bother having that bike? There was no beta testing for this game. Then there's the customization for looks and performance. The biggest mistake Milestone has in this area is completely ignoring the significance of a rear shock. The whole customization is an insult to any enthusiasts who love to customize their motorcycle's performance capability. Front forks are all stock upgrades. No chance of changing oil, springs, or even valves. Seat height, wheelbase, sprocket size, rotor size, handlebar vs clipons, removal of DOT required parts like lights. Milestone also only includes a very small amount of tracks despite having the license rights to the tracks in MotoGP15. None of those tracks appear in this game. Some tracks are ridiculously unfit for racing. Miami circuit being the most obvious because the street is too damn narrow . All in all RIDE is a game made by a casual company  meant for the casual gamer. If you want a game that shows the dedication to the sport like Tourist Trophy did for the Playstation 2, you will be very disappointed.

												I wanted to like this game, but I can't. It has fundamental flaws that make it unenjoyable for me.This is a shame because the content (the tracks, bikes, music etc) is all really good. I also got decent enough performance (outside of the load times).The worst problem is the handling. I think I figured out what the main 'cause' is, and this seems systemic of all Milestone bike games I've played:The tyres float across the track. You can see this even when not moving. Just lean left and right and look at the back tyre, it glides right and left respectively across the surface of the track when it should remain in the same place. This effect only gets worse at higher speeds, with the tyres gliding left or right by almost a whole foot when leaning.This isn't just the contact patch moving to the side of the tyre, its the whole tyre sliding as if there is no contact patch, and its not a power slide (it happens all the time), and it seemingly affects all 'modes' (pro and the rest).Overall this make the bikes horrible to handle.It's like there is no physics between the tyre and the track surface, as if the pivot point when leaning is somewhere in the middle of the bike instead of at the contact patch of the tyres. This is absolutely not a 'simulation', it's an arcade game (and, imo, a very flawed one at that).Also, some of the rider animations/'physics' are super messed up (like a crazy 'superman' somersault your rider will do during endos).And annoyingly there appears to be no practice or quali sessions, so to practice new tracks you have to go to Time Trials, which involves going through a bunch of slow loading menu screens.The other issues I had are mainly UI related:- Terrible loading screens throughout the menus.- Split time between riders not shown in-game.- Best lap time not shown in game.- Being unable to change controls in-game (have to exit out to the main menu first).- Being unable to un-assign controller buttons (so nothing is mapped to it).- Being unable to assign multiple buttons to single actions.- Unnecessary confirmation screens, like having to click proceed instead of backing out after a race, or having to re-confirm your bike (when you select a race your bike is already chosen, then get a loading screen, then have to choose your bike again - even if you only have 1 bike, then get another loading screen).- Game trying to 'sync' and failing, causing an error message you have to confirm. You can switch 'sync' off, but it re-enables itself each time the game is restarted.- Having to manually re-purchase enhanced oil after every single race.- A second or two delay between model updating when changing visual stuff (like helmets, leathers, bike parts etc), making custimising a time consuming process.- Key prompts always being for keyboard keys, even when using a controller.Some of the above may seen like nit-picking, and it is, but each little inconvenience adds up.Maybe some of the above has fixes and I missed it, but if I did its not obvious to me where it is.A real shame. So close to being a great game, yet so far.

												I'm going to compare this title a lot to MotoGP 14 because that's the game I've been playing alongside this.Ride has an overall feeling of being unpolished and rushed. Riding in the cockpit view reveals some horrible mirror reflections (if you can even call it that) and some messed up reflections on most wind screens. I really thought they would fix this before the official release but no, it's still there and it looks really bad. The graphics can look pretty good at times and pretty bad other times, often being somewhere in between. I feel MotoGP 14 is having a bit more consistency in the graphics department although it has some problems as well.The engine sounds are mostly uninspiring and often really dull sounding in my opinion (I play in cockpit view), although the engine sound gets a bit better on some of the supersport bikes. This problem, again, is shared at times in MotoGP 14. Sounds other than the engines are lacking as well (the wind starts to blow at 200 km/h). I can't comment on the music because I always turn it down in racing games.The handling of the bikes in Ride is stiffer and a bit more forgiving than in MotoGP 14 and this, for me, takes away from the fun. I think MotoGP 14 manages to pull off a lot better handling, although it might take a bit longer to get used to than in Ride.The implementation of upgrading your bike is very lacking in my opinion. I like that sort of thing in games like Forza or Gran Turismo but in here it just feels like a tacked on feature with a lot of unused potential. I actually prefer the "level up" system in MotoGP 14 even though that has some unused potential as well. Maybe a combination of the two could be pretty sweet. It's pretty cool to be able to customize the look of the bikes but again, it is lacking there as well as there are mostly minor changes that you can adjust.The carrer and the way you progress through the game is obviously taken from games like Forza and Gran Turismo but it never really captivated me here, while I often have a difficult time trying to put down the controller playing MotoGP 14.I keep trying to like this game but it just isn't that good, in my opinion. It can function as an alright break from the more solid MotoGP 14 with Ride's different types of bikes and tracks but most of the time I just can't get enough enjoyment out of this game to keep playing it for a lengthy period of time, even though it does have its moments.It is really hard to decide if I sould recommend this game or not. I'd say only get it on a sale if it's really cheap unless you're a big fan of bike games.+ A pretty nice collection of bikes and tracks you won't find in most other bike sims.+ Sometimes the graphics shine for those screenshots of you favourite bikes.+ Some events are actually pretty fun.- Bike handling feels pretty stiff in my opinion.- Graphics errors are way too prominent and hard to look past (if you're riding in cockpit view).- The sound is really lacking overall, with some exeptions.- Upgrade system feels rushed.- Prone to crash

												Ride is probably the best motorcycle video game since Tourist Trophy on PS2. There's been many MotoGP and WSBK games, but not many that use real-world motorcycles. I do enjoy riding some of the lesser known, or less racing-orientated bikes, its unusual.The gameplay is good, not amazing, but good. Sometimes the rider can be a little sluggish, almost like a deliberate input lag of sorts. Its most noticeable when switching directions quickly in a chicane, the rider will be noticeably delayed in swapping his body position on the bike. Sometimes the 'simulation' style of gameplay where excessively hard braking or hard acceleration causes the bike to squirm or slide aren't particularly smooth or realistic. The best motorcycle engine noises in a video game ever, are in Burnout Paradise. And bikes are a side show in that game! Come on! Get your act together.Summary:Pros:- Great Selection of bikes, even some older 80's and 90's calssics.- Fast access to decent bikes, no need to spend hours riding slow bikes (unless you want to).- Decent on-bike graphics.- Decent controls.- Bike customization is limited, but still relatively well implemented. Bikes sound dreadful.- Some glaring omissions as far as bikes are concerned.- Helmetless riders look ridiculous, very dated.- Controls can sometimes feel delayed.- Some occassional dodgey slides where the physics don't add up.- Bike customization could have been better. 												This game undoubtedly has a good graphical set-up with some seriously good visuals to give your eyes something nice to see. Although be it good looking, it's not exactly the best in it's entire delivery.Now, I have played motorsport racing games prior that not only include a Nintendo classic but MotoGP 13 as well. In my personal opinion, MotoGP 13 is probably one of the best racing games out there. I personally do not think Ride gives it a run for it's money but does have a few perks of it's own. Ride is a motorcycle racing game that entices players with it's various bike selection and decent gameplay. The selection of bikes ranges from naked bikes, historical bikes to super bikes each with their own sort of feel (regarding handling) and power. I start off with this point as it's the most influential part of the game as all the big names from Triumph, Kawasaki, Yamaha to KTM are all here. The rest is give or take - alright at best.The control scheme is decently immersive and accurate at certain times. There is the manual tuck that the player can choose to activate on top of other manual options (brake assistance and transmission settings). The braking system feature for example has two separate buttons for front brake and rear brake. Cool because that does make sense. The issue here though is the handling and braking throughout the turns (or before I should say). That "stiff" feeling of turning or tapping your stick to the right or left is still there. Instead of punishing the player for letting go of the left stick (turning control) too quickly, the rider slowly comes back to an upright position. Even if you're fooling around and tapping the stick left and right, it still has a choppy motion instead of a smooth movement.I understand the player is flicking the stick but as I've said, the game should punish sloppy or quick movements that would break a trajectory. On top of that, the turning doesn't feel as rewarding as it should. In MotoGP 13, taking a turn at a high speed and keeping that lean was what made it epic. Here, it doesn't really feel like you're doing anything epic at all, just another turn so to speak. What I will give the game credit for though is coming out of a turn. This feels like it was done right especially with higher powered bikes. If the player begins to floor the gas (so to speak) the bike's rear tire will start spinning out of control and slowly start putting the player at risk. The effects of this are cool and do make for split second decisions in how to recover. Problem is even if you do sort of muck up, the rider will go through a small animation looking like he's falling then recover given you did your part. These animations feel stiff and don't move with the bike as well as are sort of misleading. The crashes in MotoGP 13 felt a lot better than they do here (according to my personal contrast)! I think the animations could have been more relative rather than putting the same one for every situation.The graphics as I've mentioned are really good and the visuals and details on the bikes are quite excellent. Problem is games not only have to look good, they should also play well. The bike designs will make you stop for a moment and especially enjoy any modifications you've made to the bike (which can be seen). Then there are small things like nothing reflecting properly off the mirrors that could drive someone nuts. Some tracks it seems as though they put a repeating loop onto the mirrors. What is nice is that you'll see your player switching gears and letting go of the gas. The sounds are relatively good (not the best) but does give the player something different to listen to when switching bikes. Crash effects more or less sound the same and could have used a bit more diversity here (even though it's not the point of the game)! The music in-game is alright but I would argue the menus sound better.So why MotoGP 13 over this game? I feel that overall the other game albeit doesn't have as many bikes as Ride, still provides for a better motorcycle simulation game than this. If they made Ride more of an arcade sort of racer and mixed some simulation points into the game, I feel it could have gone better. What is completely appalling is the fact there are SO MANY LOADING SCREENS! Why does it load to a confirmation screen to show my bike once I've already chosen which bike I want to use!? Makes no sense! If you want more diversity in bikes, you may like this game. I play MotoGP in first person when I race whereas here I find I'm stuck playing in 3rd due to things not feeling exactly right. The game does boast a nice career mode where the player can take part of many world tours with different sets of bikes. On top of that, the maps are pretty good and could give the MotoGP 13 maps a run for their money. Also, the game clips randomly for me sometimes (and have noticed others having the same problem). This can be disastrous in key moments. Additionally, the leader boards don't seem to work either.I will recommend it but you'll definitely have to be a bike/race enthusiast to really enjoy it.RATING : 6.9/10 Gameplay C+ Story / Campaign B Visuals / User Interface B+ Sounds / Music C+ Replay-ability C+ Overall  C+ScreenShots : Probably one of my better screenshotsThe "go-to" animation for almost falling off a bikeI'm sure this is considered showing offStoppie and WheelieI like to start in styleWhat a naked bike looks likePeople do this in real life

												Is it perfect? No, it has issues. But I've not experienced anything game breaking, and ultimately I found RIDE incredibly enjoyable. In a world where the last "Forza/GT but with bikes" came out 10 years ago, you have to overlook what I feel a minor inconveniences and enjoy a rare release. Having played a lot of Milestone's previous bike games (all the way back to EA Sports Superbike 2001) probably helps, as they have made incremental improvements to what I feel is a rock solid riding model. Sure, its not GP Bikes, but there's a reason why no mainstream release has tackled simulating the weight shifting/countersteering that it takes to truly ride a bike, its an extra level of complication that would simply be a very large barrier for some people to overcome to find enjoyment. But all the right elements are there, braking points, lean angle and throttle application. A hold-trigger-to-go arcade racer its not. The knock against Milestone is they barely supported this game, with limited fixes and some incredibly content light DLC, and seemingly they are moving on to producing a sequel. So I can understand peoples' grievances in this regard for a self-published title (where a developer would usually be subjugated to the whims of a 3rd party publisher)I recommend this game with caveats; if you have a grunty system, and an affinity for bikes (or Milestones' previous bike sims). However I don't recommend getting anything more than the basic release, and if money's tight or you simply have a passing interest, wait for a sale.

content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
												As far as motorcycle games go, I've played none better.  Well, truth be told, I've played none at all, but as a rather adventurous real-life rider who cut his teeth on the winding roads of Oregon's wine country and coastal mountain range, I can say that the physics and bike handling are spot-on.  Especially when traction control is off, taking a corner too wide and getting off-road while leaned over will often result in a low-side bail, just like real life.  Cornering correctly at the highest speed you can, only to lean in the other direction and take the next, has a lot of weight, as it should; and it's very satisfying to get it right.  This does impart a certain learning curve since, even though bikes can "turn on a dime," they can't literally turn on a dime; there are nuances to the timing of brakes, throttle, and cornering that are not the same with cars, and you notice it much more when using a controller.  There's a certain finesse to timing ahead for your corners, but though some may feel that this makes the game unplayable, I find the challenge refreshing, and the difficulty not at all unfair.The graphics are decent and the framerate stays smooth on my four-year-old computer (three-year-old graphics card) using maximum settings and 1.5GB environment textures.  I'd like to see how this looks on a newer computer, but alas... money.The sound is where I have to dock some points.  While there's not much you can do to accurately synthesize an engine's sound and make it react to user input without reams of code (that I know of...), the bikes sound good, considering.  It's during momentous occasions such as crashes where the sound design really stinks, because while there might be a clunk or two, there's no horrible crunch, no grinding of metal and fiberglass as your bike flips and slides down the road, no scraping of leather as your character does the same.  It really removes a lot of impact from a corner taken too fast or too late.Lastly, beware the bugs.  I read that this was originally slated for Stateside release in June, but I have it, and it seems as though it should have been held back until then.  I enjoy it quite a bit, but it's very irritating that my Ducati Diavel's exhaust pipes, turn signals, license plate, intake grills, and mirror stalks are all invisible.  I've heard of other people experiencing similar issues with graphics, and this really shouldn't be in a finished product.All in all, though, foibles aside, I am having a ton of fun with Ride.  I now live in southern Minnesota, where you can't push your bike's cornering ability without risking a year's income on a potential speeding ticket, so this comes close to taking care of my lean cravings.  Hopefully Milestone will have a patch soon to take care of the bugs, and maybe the sound problems.  In any case, though, buy this game if you want a proper bike simulator.  It rips.

												So far, I've got o say Ride hit the mark on a niche role that the MotoGP games weren't filling.Pros: -Over 100 bikes-Over 400 different paint jobs-from 390-1200cc bikes -Naked bikes/sports/supersports/superbikes/track bikes/prototypes-The actual gameplay feels smooth (when you use correct graphic settings)-Can change things like fender eliminators and mirror elminators, tires, lever colors, triple clamp colors.-Rider gear can be custumized from helmet (they even have my skin of the AGV K3), gloves, boots, suits, pants, and jackets-Riding position can be made custom, and that's really cool little feature for me personally-You can REALLY feel the difference in bikes. I power wheeied up several times, hit the throttle too hard out of corners and slid out. Things I was doing that aren't always good practice (powering early out of turns, opening wide up in lower gears) were fine on the R6, but on the Duc, double the power it was very clear that I had to race much cleaner. Cons:-I feel the "Racing Line" they have is a tad off at times, there's definitely points where I can clearly break after it tells me to/lines that are more optimal to take wide/short. Looking at you Road America-The racing line isn't always clear on when to lean, Often times I can go early to get a jump on the apex. While other times if I turn when it wants me to I'll come up short on the turn.-The starting bikes are incredibly lopsided. I went with the 636 Monster, and it was a clear loser to the speed triple. I struggled very much to even finish on the podium with the Ducati. But when I started over, with the triple, it was a walk in the park to finish top.-I don't feel the tracks are varied enough in world tour mode. I've seen Road America, Imola, and Miami plenty of times. I've only seen Wales once, and yet to see Sierra Nevada. -I wish they did more with the salt flats track, It's a big relaxer to just drag it up, but I think they could do a little more with it. Maybe a mode where you try to beat your top speed?-Bike damage is nonexistant, I'd like to see a hardcore mode.Overall, I think Ride is shaping up to be the niche motorcycle riders, enthusiants, and race enthusiants are looking for. However, there are minor tweaks that need to be made, and some content as far as tracks go I'd love to see added (Isle of Man TT [PLEASE, even if it's just a segement of the track] , Leguna Seca, Catalunya, Mugello).For now, I'd give it an 8/10, hopefully Milestone actually sticks with this to provice patches, and new content.For $40, I'd say it's definitely a save bet for any motorcycle rider.

												A brief analysis:- A could-have-been-better-but-not-bad list of motorcycles:  there are some emblematic bikes, such as the Yamaha YZF R1 and R6, Kawasaki Ninja, Ducati 1199, Honda Fireblade and others, along with some older models like the FZR750R, but the list of available bikes feels somewhat incomplete, especially when compared to Tourist Trophy, which boasted a much more varied list of available vehicles;- On the other hand, RIDE has got a good selection of tracks, with plenty of challenging tracks and well-modeled environments. There are some courses that may be familiar to most racing game aficionados, like Donington Park and Imola, along with original tracks;- Gameplay is OK. Handling feels realistic (and becomes really unforgiving with riding aids turned off), the bikes have a good response to input (some of the more powerful motorcycles may be tricky to control), and there are different camera angles to choose from (dashboard view's the best for riding, in my opinion). However, framerate is very unstable (and too laggy when the screen's crowded; it sometimes gets to a point where this problem actually has the potential of ruining your races) and, sadly, it never reaches the oft-desired 60 frames per second.- Sound is great. The bikes sound like their real-life counterparts, and the ambient sound is also OK. Soundtrack is forgettable, but not bad.Need some high-speed two-wheeled action? RIDE may be the game you're looking for. It has the potential to be onde of the best riding games available once you learn to deal with failures, but it definitely feels like something is missing. If you prefer a wider variety of tracks and vehicles, you should stick with Tourst Trophy instead. - 8/10

												As someone who rides a motorcycle in reality yet can't ride anything bigger than 125cc due to some stupid British law, I figured buying this game would somewhat alleviate the desire for more speed, and it has. Not entirely but to some degree it has. In terms of gameplay this game is fantastic, going round corners at god knows what speed looks and feels awesome, the physics seem lifelike (from what I can tell), and it is genuinely challenging if you turn up the AI difficulty and turn the assists off. Racing in this game is by far the best fun I've had in a video game this year. The only thing that's bad about the gameplay is the godawful engine sounds. The Aprillia RS250 sounds like the various speeds on a marital aid as you go up through the revs, the Suzuki GSXR1000 K5 sounds muffled, as if you've got your ears plugged and all of the V-Twin Ducati's just sound boring. One of the most significant things about a motorcycle is that they resemble what hell would sound like, not what a hairdryer sounds like. Aside's from the barely viable engine sounds, the gameplay is fantastic.The menu's however are not. Sure, the backgrounds are pretty, but the text and text boxes are just bland. Navigating the menu's is like trying to force spaghetti up a cat's backside. I have spent a good 3 out of my current 16.7 hours playing this game sidescrolling left and right, be it trying to choose/upgrade a bike, pick an event or simply change my character's helmet. However, ironically, when you're about to purchase yourself a new motorcycle and you go to pick a manufacturer to choose from, all of said manufacturer's are laid out in a nice, easy to navigate grid menu, yet once you pick your desired motorcycle manufacturer you go back to the slow, dimwitted sidescrolling mess that they call a  menu, it's like being stuck in a world of Soup with only a fork. Why is that simple, easy to use grid menu not implemented in ANY OF THE OTHER MENU'S? So in conclusion, if you manage to make it through the seven levels of menu hell and start a race, you will enjoy yourself. Hopefully they'll improve the engine sounds because right now they barely resemble anything that combusts. TL:DRGameplay is good, apart from the poor engine sounds.Menus are difficult to navigate and as aesthetically pleasing as a small bowl of vomit balanced on Emma Watson's nose.

												Despite all the negative reviews, I decided to give this a try..and boy, how wrong these reviews are is incredible! When it comes to the bike models, the level of details and customization, it is a masterpiece. You will spend 80% of the first race just looking at your bike and be impressed, they look awesome! The bikers customization is also on par with many options and gear to choose from. The sounds though..might use some improvements, but they are not as bad to force you stop playing. The ingame options are limited to sound and hud, the rest is either managed by your GPU's control panel or the game's launcher. Overall it is an ARCADE, don't expect super physics, feedback from the tires or anything that could make it feel more realistic or sim-like, it is 100% arcade. They clearly spent all the money on the licenses and the amazingly good looking models and left the gameplay and overall feels somwhere..far from the game xD. I will list the things you will read the most in the negative reviews and try to explain/solve them if possible:FPS drops - Yes, the drops were there when no fps lock was in place, from 120 to 80 on different areas on the same track. As this game is a console port you can't expect it to work over 60 fps without drops. Lock to 60 using your GPU's control panel and you will be fine. It NEVER dropped below 60 for me. Long loading times - Lies. Got the OS on SSD and the game running from a 5900 rpms HDD and it takes like 15 seconds, sometimes less, to start racing. Corrupt saves - As simple as backing up your save after each session. Yes, it is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ but if you are a bike nurrrrd and like the game, you won't have any problems with doing a simple copy-paste. Game keeps running in the background. Close Logitech's Profiler and problem solved.Crash on loading screen. Don't press any buttons at all during loading screens and voila, no crashes. Bad AI. I agree, to a certain point. The AI is not bad, it can be a real challenge, specially at the beginning, even more if you go with the Yamaha as your first bike, but from time to time they might act like you are not there, crash into you and force you to either finish in the last positions or restart. It is annoying, yes, but, you can simply avoid them by keeping your distance or using the rewind thingy to go back in time. Xbox controller not working. I am guessing these people were using third party "xbox" controllers and they did not work because the original one from MS works pefectly fine. In menus and in races. For 9.99 € it is worth every cent.

												Wow, what a game! -8/1010 hours playedMotorcycle owner/fan*MUST BE PLAYED WITH A CONTROLLER*- I can not emphasize this enough There is no way to get the accuracy and finesse required out of a keyboard(at least using the most realistic physics). With a controller not only can you modulate the gas, brakes, and turning angle in a fluid way (which is extremely important to get a clean line), but you also get force feedback-which adds to the experience immensley. Every shift has a little rumble to it, you can feel when your tires are reaching/passing their grip threshold, and it's much easier to tell when you're close to the wall/another rider. I would not bother playing this game without one.PROTIP FOR NEXT GAME- VR/steam controller native suppourt would be amazing.Pros:-Good graphics, Excellent detail in all of the bike models, all the way down to the proper speedo/tach layout.-The tracks are fun and challenging, once again a lot of work went into making sure everything felt real, right down to the skidmarks on the road. Additional tracks would be nice, even as dlc(pikes peak pls). The crowds are your standard racing game low detail model but that really isn't why one plays the game.-A decent amount of character customization and an excellent amount of riding style customization. I was amazed when I figured out how tweakable this was.-The reverse function is super helpful when having issues with a certain corner. It allows you to reverse approximately the last 15 seconds and even change cameral angles to figure out exactly what the issue is. This feature should be in every racing game-The first person perspective inside the helmet is very involving. The sensation of speed has been translated very well to a video game, even including accurate sounding wind buffeting, blurring of vision and helmet shaking.-The mechanics, for the most part, are faithfully accurate to motorcycling. Using the brakes properly has been the hardest thing for me to figure out but I am starting to get it. *Big asterisk* There is no clutch control, which, while really only needed for starting, still removes a major component of a race, especially in drag races. This would be an awesome addition to subsequent games.-Extensive motorcycle roster--includes basically every major production superbike and naked bike from 2015 - INCLUDING THE MOTHERF***ING LIGHTNING 218 OMGGGGGG. All bikes have all the main customization options that are normally changed. I wish the was a bit more variety of options in a few areas, namely tires and rims but that really isn't an issue.-A decent amount of bike setup customization including, preload, spring stiffness, and preload with the top tier suspension, and full gearbox ratio customization with the top tier gearbox. *Things to add* Steering angle, more levels of gearbox and suspension customization, rear swingarm length, steering dampener settings, ecu timing and fueling, new throttle profiles, and EXTREMELY IMPORTANTLY, the ability to change settings on the fly to feel the difference and make it easier to experiment with different setups to find what works for you. It's annoying to have to go through three loading screens everytime you want to make an adjustment. A dyno would be nice too.Cons, and there are a few big ones:-THE BIGGEST PROBLEM WITH THIS GAME--Bike sound. While the sounds of different bikes vary appropriately according to displacment, engine arrangement, and exhaust, it's very obvious that not much money was put toward making the bikes sound real. When you're making a game with the sole intent of creating the most accurate bike simulator out there, this is hugely important. Does it do the job? Yes, I can shift at the proper time based on the sound. Does it add to the experience? NO. It most definitely removes from it. All the bikes have this wierd low quality synthesizer-esque sound that is just bad. I almost didn't buy the game because of this. The exhaust and intake systems should also have a more realistic effect on the overall sound. -Controller integration, while superb with actual gameplay, does not properly transfer to the replay and picture taking functions. There is no way for me to save screenshots, which might be an issue with keyboards as well. Many of the main and contextual menus do not properly display controller buttons. Also, RB is reserved for the chat function which I'm sure most people will not be using--especially in the MIDDLE OF A RACE. Complete absurdity.-No way to practice on a track in career mode-just an extra hassle and a few loading screens to switch to time trial but nevertheless annoying for something that is so essential to the game.-No real sense of career progression at least in this point in the game. It feels like there's just a bunch of tracks that I will eventually win. The player should start out in low stakes, low displacement, public, ametur races and have to work their way up to the big leagues. The amount of money you get from even the lowest tier career mode races is enough to buy a new bike every 2-3 races. While it's nice to have access to the coolest bikes right from the get go it cheapens their value. All bikes should be available outside of career mode, but you should really have to work to earn them inside it.-Mirrors do not functionAdditional ways for the game to be improved:-More extensive career mode. Sponsorship, factory and private teams, custom works parts, rivalries, greater acceptance of non-podium spots(to encourage playing on harder modes), qualifying, no restarts on official races(although I feel the rewind function to be neccesary to deal with the random crap that comes with the fact that this is a simulation and not real life), better integration of team members, multiple seasons, and more varied lengths of races are some ways to improve this.-Tire, brake pad, slider, and chain wear would all be nice to see in addition to the already existing need to replace oil every few races (which is a nice touch)-More bike customization options. Super/Turbocharging, Fuel injection system hardware, High-compression heads and forged pistons and cranks, different camshaft profiles, frame sliders, and more Colour options. Only being allowed to use the factory available colours is pretty crappy.-Easier to navigate menus. Mostly evident in the bike customization menu, categories with many colour options are all one massive list. The different styles should be listed independently of colour selection.-A drafting element-A NFSU2 style free roam would be neatTL;DRA good game provided you can get past the sound. A lot of attention to detail even though this game doesn't seem to have been made on a large budget. Mechanics are good but must be played with a controller. If you like motorcycles and video games, buy it.

I played SBK X for a while and I liked that one as well, IF you've played a milestone bike game you should feel at home.Still some problems with the not so realistic feel of the bike sometimes, I mean a bike is VERY nimble in real life, you can lean from one side to the other very quickly : in this game you have to change suspension settings to get closer to reality, and you get negative effects from that (less stability).Still this is acceptable and you can have a lot of fun.Does not have a lot of tracks at the moment, which is strange because they already had them in earlier games (in SBK X and previous moto GP games you had most popular tracks like brno, mugello, mazda raceway laguna seca etc. A few open road tracks : need way more real open roads (and i mean not going in circles with laps, i mean a real road like there are sometimes in rally games)Also city tracks , which I dont like so much (all 90° turn... it gets old)Lots of bikes ! That's awesome. very well detailed, many categories like historical, naked, sportbikes, of all displacements. Some groups are unbalanced for racing (you get MT07 or 696 pitted against a 848 , I think they should categorize in relation with horsepower instead of displacement.)Other example in supersport category: 600cbr, 636 ninja, MV agusta 800 3 cylinder : too much difference in hpWasn't very expensive so I got what a paid for but.. I really hope they develop on this base because it could very well be a wonderful title.I won't hesitate to buy DLC's to expand on it (bikes, tracks)So.. why do I not recommend it ? -Milestone is deaf and mute , PR is nowhere to be seen, many users have game breaking bugs and nothing happens-Loading screens are actually preventing me from launching the game right now, I mean it feels like playing playstation 1 back in the day
